Explain the difference between TCP and UDP protocols.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### TCP vs. UDP Comparison

| Feature | TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) | UDP (User Datagram Protocol) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Connection** | Connection-oriented (Handshake required) | Connectionless (No handshake) |
| **Reliability** | High (Guarantees delivery & order) | Low (Best effort, packets may drop) |
| **Speed** | Slower (Overhead from error checking) | Faster (Minimal overhead) |
| **Flow Control** | Yes (Manages data flow rate) | No (Sends explicitly) |
| **Use Case** | Web browsing (HTTP), Email (SMTP) | Streaming, Gaming, VoIP |

TCP is reliable but heavier; UDP is fast but risky.

Compare the Federalists and Anti-Federalists during the US ratification debates.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Federalists vs. Anti-Federalists

| Issue | Federalists | Anti-Federalists |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Core Belief** | Strong central government is necessary for order. | Strong central government threatens liberty. |
| **Constitution** | Supported ratification as written. | Opposed; demanded a Bill of Rights. |
| **Economy** | Commercial/Industrial focus. | Agrarian/Farming focus. |
| **Key Figures** | Hamilton, Madison, Jay. | Jefferson, Henry, Mason. |
| **Power Base** | Urban areas, Wealthy merchants. | Rural areas, Small farmers. |

Essentially, Federalists prioritized national stability, while Anti-Federalists prioritized state sovereignty and individual rights.

How does an Electrochemical Cell (Galvanic) work?

Here is the visual breakdown:

```
        Electron Flow (e-)  --------->
    _____________________________________
   |                                     |
   |   [Voltmeter/Load]                  |
   |_____________________________________|
       |                             |
   +---|---+                     +---|---+
   | Anode | (Oxidation)         |Cathode| (Reduction)
   |  (-)  |                     |  (+)  |
   | Zn    |   [Salt Bridge]     |  Cu   |
   |       |   (Ion Balance)     |       |
   |~~~~~~~|   [=============]   |~~~~~~~|
   | ZnSO4 |                     | CuSO4 |
   | Soln  |                     | Soln  |
   +-------+                     +-------+
```

Electrons flow from the Anode (Oxidation/Loss of electrons) to the Cathode (Reduction/Gain of electrons) generating current.

What is the structure of a Doubly Linked List?

Here is the visual breakdown:

```
   NULL <---- [Prev|Data|Next] <=====> [Prev|Data|Next] <=====> [Prev|Data|Next] ----> NULL
                  Node 1                   Node 2                   Node 3
                 (Head)                                            (Tail)
```

Unlike a singly linked list, each node contains a pointer to both the **Next** node and the **Previous** node, allowing bidirectional traversal.

Differentiate between Perfect Competition and Monopoly market structures.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Perfect Competition vs. Monopoly

| Characteristic | Perfect Competition | Monopoly |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Number of Firms** | Many (Infinite ideally) | One (Single seller) |
| **Product Type** | Homogeneous (Identical) | Unique (No close substitutes) |
| **Barriers to Entry** | None (Free entry/exit) | Very High (Patents, resources) |
| **Price Control** | Price Taker (Market sets price) | Price Maker (Firm sets price) |
| **Efficiency** | Allocatively & Productively Efficient | Typically Inefficient (Deadweight loss) |

Perfect competition benefits consumers via low prices; Monopolies maximize producer profit usually at consumer expense.

Compare Equity Financing vs. Debt Financing.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Equity vs. Debt Financing

| Aspect | Equity Financing (Stocks) | Debt Financing (Loans/Bonds) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Ownership** | Dilutes ownership (sold shares) | Retain full ownership |
| **Repayment** | No obligation to repay | Must repay principal + interest |
| **Cash Flow** | Dividends (optional) | Regular interest payments (mandatory) |
| **Risk to Business** | Low (No foreclosure risk) | High (Collateral/Bankruptcy risk) |
| **Tax Impact** | Dividends are not tax-deductible | Interest payments are tax-deductible |

Equity is safer but costs control; Debt is riskier but keeps control and offers tax shields.

Differentiate between Stack and Heap memory allocation.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Stack vs. Heap Memory

| Feature | Stack | Heap |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Allocation** | Static (compile time) & Automatic | Dynamic (runtime) & Manual |
| **Access Speed** | Very Fast (LIFO structure) | Slower (Complex tracking) |
| **Management** | OS managed (auto-cleared on return) | Developer managed (garbage collection needed) |
| **Size Limit** | Limited (Risk: Stack Overflow) | Large (Limited by virtual memory) |
| **Data Type** | Local variables, function calls | Objects, global variables |

Stack is for temporary execution context; Heap is for long-living dynamic data.

Compare Mitosis and Meiosis.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Mitosis vs. Meiosis

| Aspect | Mitosis | Meiosis |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Purpose** | Growth, Tissue Repair | Sexual Reproduction (Gametes) |
| **Divisions** | One division | Two successive divisions |
| **Daughter Cells** | 2 Diploid (2n) - Identical | 4 Haploid (n) - Genetically Unique |
| **Genetic Mixing** | None (Clones) | Yes (Crossing over occurs) |
| **Occurrence** | Somatic (Body) Cells | Germ (Sex) Cells |

Mitosis clones cells for maintenance; Meiosis creates diversity for reproduction.

Show the flow of the OSI Model (Open Systems Interconnection).

Here is the visual breakdown:

```
[7] Application Layer  (User Interface/Data)    ^  (Receiver Decapsulates)
         |                                      |
[6] Presentation Layer (Encryption/Formatting)  |
         |                                      |
[5] Session Layer      (Connection Control)     |
         |                                      |
[4] Transport Layer    (TCP/UDP - Segments)     |
         |                                      |
[3] Network Layer      (IP/Routing - Packets)   |
         |                                      |
[2] Data Link Layer    (MAC/Switching - Frames) |
         |                                      |
[1] Physical Layer     (Cables/Signals - Bits)  |
```

Data travels down the stack (encapsulation) at the sender and up the stack (decapsulation) at the receiver.

Explain the difference between Ionic and Covalent bonds.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Ionic vs. Covalent Bonds

| Characteristic | Ionic Bond | Covalent Bond |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Formation** | Transfer of electrons | Sharing of electrons |
| **Participants** | Metal + Non-Metal | Non-Metal + Non-Metal |
| **State (RT)** | Solid (Crystal Lattice) | Liquid or Gas (typically) |
| **Polarity** | High Polarity | Low (Non-polar) to Medium (Polar) |
| **Example** | NaCl (Salt) | H2O (Water) |

Ionic bonds involve stealing electrons to form ions; Covalent bonds involve sharing electrons to achieve stability.

How do Fiscal Policy and Monetary Policy differ?

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Fiscal vs. Monetary Policy

| Feature | Fiscal Policy | Monetary Policy |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Controller** | Government (Parliament/Congress) | Central Bank (Fed/ECB) |
| **Primary Tools** | Taxes, Government Spending | Interest Rates, Money Supply |
| **Target** | Aggregate Demand, Budget Deficit | Inflation, Currency Stability |
| **Speed** | Slow (Legislative lag) | Fast (Immediate implementation) |
| **Political Influence**| High | Low (Ideally independent) |

Fiscal policy changes *who* has money (taxes/spending); Monetary policy changes *how much* money costs (interest rates).

Visualize Series vs. Parallel Circuits.

Here is the visual breakdown:

```
      SERIES CIRCUIT                 PARALLEL CIRCUIT

      +---[R1]----[R2]---+           +----[R1]----+
      |                  |           |            |
    [Bat]              (Bulb)      [Bat]----[R2]----+
      |                  |           |            |
      +------------------+           +----(Bulb)--+

    - One path for current         - Multiple paths for current
    - If one fails, all fail       - If one fails, others work
    - Voltage divides              - Voltage is same across branches
```

In series, components are daisy-chained; in parallel, they branch off independently.

Distinguish between Deductive and Inductive Reasoning.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Deductive vs. Inductive Reasoning

| Aspect | Deductive (Top-Down) | Inductive (Bottom-Up) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Starting Point** | General Theory/Rule | Specific Observation/Data |
| **Process** | Theory -> Hypothesis -> Confirm | Observation -> Pattern -> Theory |
| **Conclusion** | Certain (if premises are true) | Probable (Generalized guess) |
| **Usage** | Mathematics, Logic, Coding | Science, Statistics, Trends |
| **Example** | All men are mortal -> Soc is a man -> Soc is mortal | Soc died -> Plato died -> All men must be mortal |

Deduction proves what must be true; Induction infers what is likely true.

Compare SQL (Relational) and NoSQL (Non-Relational) databases.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### SQL vs. NoSQL Databases

| Feature | SQL (e.g., MySQL, Postgres) | NoSQL (e.g., MongoDB, Redis) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Structure** | Table-based (Rows/Columns) | Document, Key-Value, Graph |
| **Schema** | Rigid/Pre-defined | Flexible/Dynamic |
| **Scaling** | Vertical (Add CPU/RAM to server) | Horizontal (Add more servers/Sharding) |
| **Consistency**| ACID (Strong consistency) | BASE (Eventual consistency) |
| **Best For** | Complex queries, Financial data | Big data, Real-time apps, Content mgmt |

SQL is structured and safe; NoSQL is flexible and scalable.

Explain Classical Conditioning (Pavlov).

Here is the visual breakdown:

```
1. Before Conditioning:
   [Food] (Unconditioned Stimulus) ----> [Salivation] (Unconditioned Response)
   [Bell] (Neutral Stimulus)       ----> [No Response]

2. During Conditioning (Pairing):
   [Bell] + [Food] --------------------> [Salivation]

3. After Conditioning:
   [Bell] (Conditioned Stimulus)   ----> [Salivation] (Conditioned Response)
```

Classical conditioning creates an association between a neutral stimulus and a biologically potent stimulus to elicit a learned response.

What is the difference between Virtual Machines (VM) and Containers?

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Virtual Machines vs. Containers

| Layer | Virtual Machine (e.g., VMWare) | Container (e.g., Docker) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Top Layer** | App + Libs | App + Libs |
| **Isolation** | Guest OS (Full Operating System) | Container Engine (Shared OS Kernel) |
| **Host Layer** | Hypervisor | Host OS |
| **Size** | Heavy (GBs) | Lightweight (MBs) |
| **Boot Time** | Minutes | Seconds |

VMs visualize hardware (running full OSs); Containers visualize the OS (sharing the kernel).

Contrast Metaphor and Simile.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Metaphor vs. Simile

| Element | Metaphor | Simile |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Definition** | Direct equation of two things. | Comparison using helpers. |
| **Key Words** | "Is", "Are", "Was" | "Like", "As" |
| **Intensity** | Stronger, more abstract. | Explicit, easier to visualize. |
| **Example** | "Time is a thief." | "Time is *like* a thief." |
| **Example** | "He has a heart of stone." | "His heart is cold *as* stone." |

A simile says A is *like* B; a metaphor says A *is* B.

Compare Utilitarianism and Deontology.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Utilitarianism vs. Deontology

| Focus | Utilitarianism (Mill/Bentham) | Deontology (Kant) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Basis** | Consequence-based | Duty-based |
| **Goal** | Maximize happiness for most people. | Adhere to moral rules/duties. |
| **Means vs Ends**| The ends justify the means. | The means must be moral regardless of ends. |
| **Context** | Context matters (situational). | Universal (rules apply always). |
| **Trolley Problem**| Pull lever (Kill 1 to save 5). | Do not pull (Killing is inherently wrong). |

Utilitarianism looks at the outcome; Deontology looks at the action itself.

How does Asymmetric (Public Key) Encryption work?

```
      Sender (Alice)                         Receiver (Bob)

   [Message: "Hello"]                     [Private Key] (Kept Secret)
          |                                      ^
          v                                      |
   (Encrypt with Bob's)                   (Decrypt with Bob's)
   (   Public Key     )                   (   Private Key    )
          |                                      |
          v                                      |
   [Encrypted: "Xy7#b9"] -----------------> [Message: "Hello"]
```

You use the recipient's Public Key to lock the message, and only they can unlock it with their Private Key.

Explain the difference between a Process and a Thread.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### Process vs. Thread

| Feature | Process | Thread |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Definition** | An executing program (Heavyweight). | Smallest unit of execution (Lightweight). |
| **Memory** | Isolated (Has own stack, heap, data). | Shared (Shares heap/data with other threads). |
| **Communication** | IPC (Inter-Process Communication) - Slow. | Shared memory - Fast. |
| **Overhead** | High (Context switching is expensive). | Low (Context switching is cheap). |
| **Failure** | Process crash doesn't affect others. | Thread crash can crash the whole process. |

A Process is the factory; Threads are the workers inside sharing the same floor.

Compare DNA and RNA.

Here is the visual breakdown:

### DNA vs. RNA

| Feature | DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid) | RNA (Ribonucleic Acid) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Strands** | Double-stranded (Helix) | Single-stranded |
| **Sugar** | Deoxyribose | Ribose |

| **Insertion (Beginning)**| O(n) - Slow (Must shift all). | O(1) - Fast (Change pointer). |
| **Memory Size** | Fixed (Static). | Dynamic (Grow/Shrink). |
| **Locality** | Good (Cache friendly). | Poor (Scattered memory). |

Arrays are for fast reading; Linked Lists are for fast writing/editing.
